Posts.Content: Jun 6, 2010 10:54AM hopeful34 wrote: I have a quick question.  I am two and half weeks out from BMX w/ immed recon. (TEs)  Is it possible to have lymphedema under your arm?  It's like just above my ribs, but directly on my side.  I can't even put my arm down.  I think I have a pretty high pain tolerance.  I was down to taking a pain pill just before bed. I went to the PS Friday to get my last two drains out.  The first two he took out were a breeze, but this time I am miserable.  I am soooo swollen.  I went from finally being able to do things around the house to barely being able to get out of bed.  My husband is back to helping me up.  I look like a body builder on my left side.  I wish I had a way to show you, but my camera isn't working.  Maybe, my mom can come take a picture.  I can't seem to find any pictures of where my pain and swelling are.  I am now back to taking pain meds every 4 hours too.  I hate this!  Please tell me what I should do.  I have my first appt with my BS tomorrow, but is it safe to wait?  Thanks in advance and any help would be greatly appreciated.  Allison
Posts.Title: VISIBLE SIGNS OF LYMPHEDEMA - A PICTORIAL LindaLou53 glennie19

Posts.Content: Sep 26, 2010 10:23PM hopeful34 wrote: Te's are Tissue Expanders.  They are use for immediate reconstruction and filled for several months before the actual implant is placed.  As far as the scars go, I had a BMX w/ immed recon (TE's) in May and I too developed an infection and had the left TE removed, so one side is concave on me as well. I will say at least with the right breast where I have the TE still, the scar has started looking alot more normal.  I think you just need to give it time.  I too was worried before, but it has faded and gotten better looking.
Posts.Title: Scars Halah loonlover

Posts.Content: Jul 10, 2010 11:15PM hopeful34 wrote: Just thought I would chime in about the stress thing.  I certainly don't have a many problems as some of you have had to deal with, but I have always been neurotic.  I always stress out.  I was going to nursing school full time, working full time and raising a fourteen year old.  I have looked into this alot.  If you google stress and estrogen levels, you will find alot of articles on this.  I don't necessarily think stress causes cancer, but it is proven that stress triggers estrogen levels to raise, and for someone like me who is ER+, I can't help but think my stress may have triggered the cancer cell growth.  I have a quote from an article. "Stress plays a major role in estrogen overproduction by triggering an elevated level of cortisol, which interrupts the feedback loop between the brain, pituitary, and the ovaries that regulates hormones."  I am sorry everyone is having such a tough time.  I wish everyone well and hope we find a cure for this BC crap soon.  Take Care.  Allison
Posts.Title: Stress and Breast Cancer lukejessesmom texasrose361

Posts.Content: Jun 28, 2010 10:51AM hopeful34 wrote: Karen- If you need to send a message to Milissa to exchange information (email, address, etc.) you just click on the member name (in blue/bold) and once you do that, it will take you to a new screen.  When you get to the new screen, on your far top right, there is an option that says send member a private message.  Click on that, compose your message, and then send.  To retrieve Milissa's reply, you go to the top of the page where it says Private Messages.  When she emails you back, it will say (1 new) in white bold lettering below the private message part.  (Sorry if I got a little too detailed.) Take Care. Milissa- I am sorry to hear about the loss of your mother.  I am sure it is very hard.  You are such a wonderful woman to offer to help someone with her prosthetics.  As someone who had to get donated items myself, I can tell that it means so much to the person receiving the help.  Take Care and God Bless.  Allison

Posts.Content: Apr 16, 2011 04:58PM hopeful34 wrote: I paged the doctor three times today and he finally called me back.  It was the doctor on call, not my PS.  He said to apply warm water and soap and to call Monday and they will probably have to remove the TE again.  I think he was too busy to understand what I was saying.  I don't think it's quite that serious yet.....or at least I hope so.  His phone kept cutting out too, so I am not sure he is getting what I'm saying.  He was the least compassionate man I have ever talked to.  I mean he immediately said they'd have to remove it.  How the hell does he know?  Anyway, I am sitting til Monday I guess.  I sure hope it doesn't get worse, bc the dr doesn't have time to deal with me.
Posts.Title: Infected Stitch? Scared! hopeful34 hopeful34

Posts.Content: hopeful34 wrote: I will try to make this short.  I had my BMX last May with immediate recon.  I developed cellulitis and had to have my left TE removed.  I had surgery to put the TE back in on March 7th.  I have had two fills.  When I went in two weeks ago the surgeon noticed a stitch under the skin and he removed it.  I noticed tonight that the place he removed the stitch was red and about the size of a pimple.  I pushed on it and smelly pus came out.  Not alot, but it began to bleed bright red after the pus came out.  I am worried that I have an infection again and since it's Friday I don't know if I am okay to wait til Monday or if I should page the doctor.  I know it might not sound bad, but I am really scared.  I can't go through losing the expander again.  If it fails this time, he wants me to try the DIEP and I just don't know that I can do that.  I have been off work for a year between surgeries, infections, and chemo.  I need to get back to work, and if this infected who knows when that will be.  Has anyone else had this experience and had it be okay with abx and not surgery?  Any advice is appreciated.  Thanks.  Allison Dx 4/9/2010, IDC, 2cm, Stage IB, Grade 3, 0/3 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Surgery 5/20/2010 Mastectomy; Reconstruction (left): Silicone implant; Reconstruction (right): Silicone implant Dx 6/22/2015, Left, Stage IV, metastasized to lungs, Grade 3, ER+/PR+, HER2- Hormonal Therapy Arimidex (anastrozole), Faslodex (fulvestrant), Tamoxifen pills (Nolvadex, Apo-Tamox, Tamofen, Tamone) Chemotherapy TAC Hormonal Therapy Arimidex (anastrozole) Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Infected Stitch? Scared! hopeful34 hopeful34

Posts.Content: Apr 15, 2011 09:35PM hopeful34 wrote: I just called their office and it says to go to the ER for emergencies.  I don't know what to do.  I am afraid someone who is not familiar with my case will look at me like I am crazy for panicking about a tiny bump.  It has stopped draining and I am in alot of pain, but I assume that is from the fill still.  Do you think it is safe for me to wait til morning?
Posts.Title: Infected Stitch? Scared! hopeful34 hopeful34

Posts.Content: Apr 15, 2011 09:11PM hopeful34 wrote: I forgot one thing.  My PS put 90 cc's in two days ago.  He said I have a seroma, but nothing to worry about.  He did say yellow stuff would drain, but as long as it is not pus, don't worry.  The problem is, I think he was referring to the area where the needle went in.  This is coming out of the end of my scar where the stitch was removed.  Sorry for rambling.
Posts.Title: Infected Stitch? Scared! hopeful34 hopeful34

Posts.Content: Apr 24, 2010 02:32PM hopeful34 wrote: I am 34 and have IDC, but they think it is stage one.  My breast surgeon told me when I asked about the double mast, that if she were my age she would have a double too, for precautionary reasons.  Obviously you have other options, but for peace of mind, I thought having the surgery and getting the worry over with far outweighed having to fool with this beast again.  I am scheduled for may 5th.  I don't know how soon you need to decide, but i will let u know how it goes.  Ultimately it is your decision.  Don't take it lightly.  Good luck to you.  I will keep u in my thoughts and prayers.  Allison

Posts.Content: Jun 3, 2010 01:35AM hopeful34 wrote: Jess, I am sorry to hear about your worrying.  It is absolutely normal to worry....especially considering your family history and you are so young.  The good news is I think it is like 80% of all breast lumps are benign.  Also, I would definately get the MRI.  I am 34 and my doctor said alot of younger women have very dense breast tissue making it hard to see lumps on mammos.  You said you had an ultrasound though right?  That is good also.  My lump did not show up on mammo, but did show up on the ultrasound and they sent a radiologist even before they sent me home to tell me it looked suspicious and that I would need a biopsy.  If they didn't see anything on the ultrasound, you should be relieved.  I would still get the MRI, but it sounds like they are doing everything they can and still haven't seen anything so that sounds good to me.  I hope they find out what is causing your problems.  Again, it is normal to worry, so don't think you're crazy....just TRY if you can to look at the good things, and that is that your CA-125 is normal and so is your U/S.  I am pretty new to this, but I have done alot of research and if you need anything you can PM me.  Take Care.  Allison
Posts.Title: Tell Me I'm Not Insane ...Please. JessWelsch CrunchyPoodleMama

Posts.Content: Jun 14, 2010 02:52PM hopeful34 wrote: I had my husband take me to the hospital and about an hour after getting there, my sister, mom, dad, and mother-in-law, came to see me before I went back, but to be honest, I was already drugged, so I don't really remember most of it.  As far as after surgery, I was only there a day and a half, and I was so tired from the drugs, that I really don't remember talking to anyone much after either.  I just waited until I got home to visit with people.  I will say I felt a bit bad because people came to visit and I would try to make myself stay awake.  They were really understanding though.  I think they could tell I was exhausted and they just told me they would call me later and they went home.  As far as what to take to the hospital....I def. used my robe....it was really cold in the hospital!  Other than that, just the usual stuff...toothbrush, toothpaste, hair products (brush, shampoo,. etc.) clothes to wear home and slippers.   I wasn't awake enough to read or anything. As far as the surgical bra, you may want to ask your doctor is they send you home with one or not.  My doctor sent me home with two bras and all of the supplies I would need after surgery (gauze, neosporin, safety pins for drains, etc.)  If you have any questions feel free to PM me.  I will keep you in my thoughts and prayers.  Take Care!  Allison

Posts.Content: Jun 30, 2015 06:33PM hopeful34 wrote: Just diagnosed last week with mets to pleura and some lymph nodes. I go for a bone scan, chest xray, and ultrasound this Thursday. I also start my Lupron injections. I already posted this question on another thread, but I am hoping for an answer. My oncologist said no chemo just arimidex and lupron injections. She said that should hold off any spread for about six months and then we can try an oral chemo pill. Then, today the breast cancer nurse at the hospital explained to me that I should have chemo because the hormonal tx will take a month or two work. I had a liter of fluid removed via thoracentesis 10 days ago and I am in so much pain and out of breath constantly, so I believe it is back again. That is why she ordered another chest xray. Any suggestions? Experiences? etc. Thanks.

Posts.Content: May 27, 2011 04:28AM - edited May 27, 2011 04:30AM by hopeful34 Thanks everyone for the nice comments.  Lago- Thanks for resizing my photos.  Unfortunately, it doesn't just show the hair on my head, but my nice beard I got going on too.  I have thought about waxing it, but I am scared it will come back with a vengence.  Oh well, I am grateful to have hair at all I guess. Carrol- Thanks, but I didn't dye my hair.  I was worried since I am 35 that it may come back gray, but fortunately it didn't.  I actually just took the clippers and put a 1" blade on them and cut my hair over my ears and in the back.  I will go get it cut professionally in the next month or so. Kasey- I too use head and shoulders.  I read on Livestrong.com that the zinc in it is good for hair growth and it is also good while you are going through chemo to prevent rashes on your head. I was having trouble with my skin being dry for a while too.  I was using moisturizer like crazy and now I have this giant zit on my head.  My husband keeps laughing at it.  Not to toot my own horn, but I have always had good skin and lately, I look like my 15 year old son.  I seem to be going through puberty and menopause simultaneously.  Between the tissue expanders growing and my zits it's like being a teen again.  Now if I could get my aching body to feel the same way I'd be in heaven.
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: May 29, 2011 06:11AM hopeful34 wrote: tlundy- you are very pretty.  The scarf looks really nice.  aimee- 28 years! Congrats!  Have fun at the casino.  I love going to casinos.  My husband and I got married in Vegas and want to go back for our 10th anniversary.

This thread is scary with all of the recurrences.  And....everyone seems so young. Take Care everyone!  Allison

Posts.Content: Jun 14, 2010 04:34AM hopeful34 wrote: somanywomen-I have considered clinical trials if the oncotype is not covered, but I wasn't sure how to do that, so I will look into the one you mentioned...thanks. otter-  Thanks for all the info.  Before the BC diagnosis, I worked for a surgeon and part of my job was doing medical appeals, so I am hoping to not only send an appeal myself, but to have the docs office send one as well.  You are right, I have thought that the insurance company must not realize that the test is a determining factor in my treatment.  I will try to make some phone calls tomorrow explaining what the results of this test mean for me.  If that doesn't work, then maybe Genomic can get them to understand how important it is.  As I said before, I am hoping I can offer to make payments to genomic.  My biggest worry is just that the insurance not paying will hold up treatment.  According to Mary in one of the posts above it will not hold up treatment and I am hoping that is true.  I guess I will know tomorrow.  I will keep you all updated.  Thanks again for all of your help.  Allison
Posts.Title: Oncotype-not covered by insurance hopeful34 LisaAlissa

Posts.Content: Jun 24, 2010 09:40AM hopeful34 wrote: mabeln- I am by no means saying you shouldn't talk to your doctor, but I have that alot in my unaffected breast.  The lump I had in the breast cancer side alerted me because it didn't go away once I started.  Usually, they do.  My ob/gyn told me to wait til after I start and if it doesn't go away to call her.  Mine were also painful.  Again, I would get it checked to be safe, but it def. sounds like a fibroid cyst...which is normal for alot of women.  I hope you start feeling better. Take Care.  Allison
Posts.Title: please help mabeln hopeful34

Posts.Content: Apr 3, 2010 12:41AM hopeful34 wrote: I just had my mammo and ultrasound yesterday and I saw them mesauring the "black area" on the screen.  I closed my eyes hoping it wasn't anything just paranoia. The radiologist came in and said he was about 70% sure it was malignant. Oh Joy!  I go next week for my biopsy.  I am freaking out and this poem of yours is the first relatable thing I have read.  Thanks so much.  You described my anxiety perfectly.

Posts.Content: Oct 3, 2010 04:05AM hopeful34 wrote: I just had my BMX in May 2010, so it's only 5 months, but I just wanted to say THANK YOU for starting this thread.  I am very depressed the past couple days and I have been worried alot that even though I am Stage 1 I might not see my son graduate and get married etc.  (He's only 14) but this thread gave me so much hope for the future.  I am so glad to hear all the positive stories.  Congrats to all of you for making it through all of this struggle and to many more years ahead.  Take Care.  Allison

Posts.Content: Jun 28, 2015 03:48AM hopeful34 wrote: Susug, I had a double mastectomy off the bat, so no need for mammograms. My oncologist will not do scans unless something warrants doing one (pain, etc.). He just has me come back every 6 months for labs/bloodwork. The reason he had scans this time is because I was having chest pain and I have been having migraines. Also, my tumor markers were slightly elevated. Good luck to you. Thanks for the reply.
Posts.Title: Newly diagnosed Stage IV malignant pleural effusion hopeful34 paulatkc

Posts.Content: Jun 27, 2010 02:13AM hopeful34 wrote: Kate- I just had a bilat mast w/ TE's in May 2010.  I think it is nice that you are telling women about NSM.  I too wanted to do that and my surgeon said she would do it if I really wanted to, but explained that the risk in my particular case was that the nipple most times develops necrosis and has to be removed anyway.  Basically, she talked me out of it.  I wish I had gotten a second opinion though.  I really think the nipples missing is bothering far more than the breast.  I wish I had seem this post regarding recurrence rates prior to my surgery.  I had looked at pictures of the NSM since my surgery and they all seemed to look okay.  Some were uneven, but it beats having another reconstruction surgery.  To me it would have been worth it.  Take Care.  Allison
Posts.Title: Please Read If You Are Considering a Preventative MX Kate33 daniellephillips

Posts.Content: Oct 2, 2010 03:17AM hopeful34 wrote: Hello everyone.  My name is Allison.  I am 34 and had a BMX w/ TE's in May.  I developed an infection and had to have one of the TE's removed in August.  I have been having the worst pain.  My chest hurts everytime I cough...both where the muscles were cut and on my sternum.  It is a burning pain and pretty constant.  I am having trouble sleeping at night, even on the side where they kept the TE in.  My neck hurts and my  shouulder blades get shooitng pains as well.  I am so scared that I have mets or something.  I keep freaking out and crying.  I am going thru chemo right now too, so I am hoping some of this pain is from SE's and not something else.  Does any of this sound familiar to any of you?  I thought it could be PMPS....but I don't really know what it feels like.  It is definitely nerve related or at least it seems like it is.   It is shooting pains, not a dull ache or anything.  I am sorry for rambling on. I am just worried and hoping I can find a reason why my whole upper body is hurting.  Any thoughts?  Thanks for your time.  Take Care.  Allison
Posts.Title: Post Mastectomy Pain Syndrome (PMPS) Deeds Lezza13

Posts.Content: Apr 10, 2010 08:36AM - edited Apr 10, 2010 08:37AM by hopeful34   U are def right about not looking things up.  That just freaks me out more.  I have pretty much tried to stay on here and quit looking up statistics on other sites and so forth.  I think part of the reason I haven't cried too much is because until I knew what it was, I thought they were gonna tell me I had 6 months to live or something.  I can deal with anything as long as I am alive.  I will feel better once I know if it has spread anywhere.  I don't know if they will tell me that at my surgeon appt thursday or not....i hope they tell me something.  The waiting sucks.  If I knew insurance would be okay then that would help alot too.  Thanks again.
Posts.Title: Biopsy came back Invasive Ductal Carcinoma grade 3 tumor hopeful34 Cowgirl13

Posts.Content: May 7, 2010 02:29AM hopeful34 wrote: The doctor should be able to tell u if your tumor is estrogen positive.  It does take some time to find out, but definately ask them.  I know during my biopsy, they tested for it, but it took a few days longer to find out the hormone receptor status.  I hope everything works out for you.  Keep everyone here updated.  I am 34 and I am having surgery in two weeks.  I just want to say the people on here have been very helpful.  One piece of advice....make sure you don't read too much, because it will scare you.  Just talk to people who know what their talking about.  Also, remember everyone's outcome is different, so try to relax and just get better.  I will keep you in my thoughts and prayers.  Allison
Posts.Title: Confused, just was told I have breast Cancer Jennypoo Jennypoo

Posts.Content: Jun 27, 2015 07:14AM hopeful34 wrote: Oceandust, thank you for the reply. Sorry about your mom. I will pray for you and your mom. I will not give up. I will do whatever it takes. I am only 39 and my son is 19 and wants me to see him have children. I have actually calmed down quite a bit just in the last couple days. I will feel better when I know more. I had my PET scan today and I get my results on Monday. Thanks again and I hope everything goes well for your mom.
Posts.Title: Newly diagnosed Stage IV malignant pleural effusion hopeful34 paulatkc

Posts.Content: Jun 30, 2015 06:05AM hopeful34 wrote: Update: I went to the oncologist to get my results of my PET scan today. While it is still stage IV, it is the best case scenario. I only have cancer in my lymph nodes. I will be having Lupron shots monthly for the next sixth months and then oral chemo for a year or so after that, along with Arimidex. The oncologist said these two treatments should keep it from spreading for at least 2 to 3 years. I am very happy that it has not spread any further. I am having another chest xray Thursday bc they think the pleural effusion may have returned, but no biggie. Also, I am having a bone scan and ultrasound Thursday, as well. It will be a busy day for sure. Thank you so much for all of the prayers.
Posts.Title: Newly diagnosed Stage IV malignant pleural effusion hopeful34 paulatkc

Posts.Content: Jul 1, 2015 03:42AM hopeful34 wrote: You are awesome, Bestbird! Thank you so much for all of your replies. You have been so helpful. I am so sorry that I keep coming back and asking more questions. Thanks again.
Posts.Title: Newly diagnosed Stage IV malignant pleural effusion hopeful34 paulatkc

Posts.Content: Jul 1, 2015 03:20AM hopeful34 wrote: Thanks KT. I am in so much pain as it is, so I might as well go through pain for the treatment. I cannot get any sleep for lack of being able to breathe. Also, in my last post I said the oncologist said I only have mets to my lymph nodes. In the meantime, the breast cancer nurse for my hospital called and said I have cancer in the pleural space around my lung. Now, I am kind of thinking yesterday wasn't such good news after all. Does anyone have experience with what this means in terms of treatment? The lady yesterday said just to do the Lupron injections and take arimidex. The nurse today told me the hormonal treatments could take a month or two to be effective and that I should consider chemo. Any thoughts?
Posts.Title: Newly diagnosed Stage IV malignant pleural effusion hopeful34 paulatkc

Posts.Content: hopeful34 wrote: I just got something from my insurance company in the mail stating they denied coverage for the oncotype test because "the results of the test will not directly impact the treatment being delivered to the member."  I am curious if anyone else had insurance deny them and how they handled it.  Of course, it is Saturday and neither the oncotype place or the insurance company are open.  So, I get to spend the weekend worrying about it.  My BS did not want to refer me to the oncologist until I get these results back, and since they won't do it, I fear that I won't get the necassry treatment.  I am willing to pay out of pocket, as long as I can afford it.  Does anyone know how much this test costs?  Also, does anyone know if the company that does the testing is willing to do it on some sort of payment plan?  I am sorry for asking so many questions, and while this may seem like something minimal to worry about, with me being Stage I, I fear that I won't get chemo, and then I will find out later that I should have.  I do know that I have lympho-vascular invasion present, but negative lymph node involvement.  I am only 34, so of course, I want to do as much as possible.  Any suggestions?  Thanks. Posts.Content: Jun 15, 2010 05:52AM hopeful34 wrote: I just talked to Genomic Health and they said the insurance denial would not hold up the testing, so that is good news.  They also said that my insurance should cover it and if they don't I should qualify for some type of financial assistance, so that too is good news.  Anyway, thanks to all of you ladies for your help.  I am glad to know I will get the test done.  Thanks again.  Allison
Posts.Title: Oncotype-not covered by insurance hopeful34 LisaAlissa

Posts.Content: Jun 13, 2010 02:15AM hopeful34 wrote: To all of you ladies....I can't imagine knowing something could have been done, only to get the worst news possible.  For those of you with young children, I am so sorry you have to worry about seeing them grow up.  My son is 14, I am Stage 1 and I still worry all the time that I might not see him graduate college, get married, have children, etc.  I guess I should count my blessings.  I posted something earlier today stating that my insurance won't cover the oncotype test.  I am very upset about this.  For the reasons you ladies have listed.  Both my maternal and paternal grandmothers died young from Lung/Brain Cancer, so I worry that I am next.  I know the oncologist won't do chemo without the oncotype test.  It is taking everything I have not to call my insurance company and cry/scream and explain that I am 34 years old and I want to be as aggressive with this as possible.  I just had a bilat mast. w/ immed recon three weeks ago, and I would hate to think I did all this, only to have recuurence later.  I am getting medicaid right now (despite having to swallow my pride) because my insurance company I had through my employer said the breast cancer was pre-existing.  Insurance companies are far too eager to deny people.  If they were smart they would realize that early detection and treatment actually saves them money in the long run.  Maybe, they need a dose of reality themselves.  I have already decided that because they are denying my bone scans, head CT, and oncotype tests, that if I come back with mets later, I am going to do everything I can to break them.  Again, I am so sorry all of you have been ignored and are now faced with mets.  Please know that you are not alone and hopefully things will start looking up for all of you.  I will keep you in my thoughts and prayers.  Take Care.  Allison
Posts.Title: Why not? LC815 hopeful34

Posts.Content: Jun 16, 2010 06:23AM hopeful34 wrote: BTW- I spoke to Genomic Health the people that handle the oncotype and they said it would not hold up testing.  They will go ahead and do it and then they will try three times to appeal it with my insurance company.  They also said they have financial assistance and if needed I can apply for that.  So all in all I guess that is good news.  At least I will get the test completed.  Thanks for all your help ladies.  Allison
Posts.Title: Why not? LC815 hopeful34

Posts.Content: Jul 11, 2015 08:09AM hopeful34 wrote: Thanks Max. I will definitely ask my doctor about the bone loss. I will see if he can do a dexa scan or something.
Posts.Title: Newly diagnosed Stage IV malignant pleural effusion hopeful34 paulatkc

Posts.Content: hopeful34 wrote: Well I got a call yesterday from the nurse and she said come immediatly to the office because the doctor needs to talk to you.  Right then...being that I am not a complete idiot.....i knew it was bad.  I was right   Anyway, I am doing suprisingly better than I thought.  At least for the time being...I think my adrenaline is going crazy right now.  Haven't even cried yet.  I cried the whole way to the doctor, but not once at the dr office.  I feel so bad for my mom, dad, and son that I feel like I need to stay calm for them.  They said they couldn't tell me much, just that it is invasive ductal carcinoma and it is 11mm and grade 2-3 tumor and a 7 out of 9 on some scale.  I go to a breast surgeon Thursday April 15th.  I have no idea what happens next.  I guess I'll just try to remain calm (yeah right) and hope it's Stage 1 or 2.  I can take anything that has the possibility of not metastisizing.  I can't help but sit here and worry about money either.  I am in nursing school right now, and you can't miss any days so I will probably have to quit without a refund.  Also, I have had good insurance my whole life until 1/30/10, and my employer cancelled my insurance since I had to go to part time for school.  So, now I have student insurance and the insurance company is saying even though I had no lapse in coverage, since the lump was there before I got insurance it could be pre-existing.  Does anyone have any ideas of what to do about insurance?  Anyway, thanks for your thoughts and prayers.  Allison Allison Dx 4/9/2010, IDC, 2cm, Stage IB, Grade 3, 0/3 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Surgery 5/20/2010 Mastectomy; Posts.Content: Apr 11, 2010 12:50PM hopeful34 wrote: Okay I woke up sick yesterday.  I started taking antibiotics to be safe, and mucinex.  Feels like bronchitis.  Great timing!  I wish I knew this BC has not spread or anything.  Since I haven't talked to the surgeon and don't know anything, my mind just goes immediately to the idea that it has spread to my lungs.  I am trying to think positive, but until I know for sure the stage and so forth, I can't help but worry.  I just wish I would feel better.
Posts.Title: Biopsy came back Invasive Ductal Carcinoma grade 3 tumor hopeful34 Cowgirl13

Posts.Content: Apr 10, 2010 08:15AM hopeful34 wrote: Thank you.  I make too much money to get medicaid, but I do qualify for some discounts from the hospital.  My biggest worry is I want the best care and I am afraid I won't be able to get that because of my insurance situation.  I don't want to do clinical trials or anything like that because I want to do what is proven to work.  If I were older maybe, but I have a son to worry about.  I have horrible credit and no assets so loans are out of the question as well.  I wish I could quit worrying about money and worry about this stupid cancer.  Anyway, sorry for all the negativity...just worried.  Thanks again.
Posts.Title: Biopsy came back Invasive Ductal Carcinoma grade 3 tumor hopeful34 Cowgirl13

Posts.Content: hopeful34 wrote: I haven't been on here posting for many years. I was originally diagnosed with Stage I bc in 2010. Well, when I went for my five year checkup in April my tumor markers were slightly elevated. Fast forward to last week and I had almost a liter of fluid drained from my right lung. They tested it and this morning I was informed my cancer had returned (at least in the pleural fluid) I go Friday for a PET scan and next Monday to discuss the results and treatment options. I don't really know what I am up against here. Does anyone have experience with this? Thank you. I do know it's not in my brain, due to a CT scan, so hopefully nothing will change on the PET scan. So, I guess that's positive news. Posts.Content: Jun 25, 2015 08:10AM hopeful34 wrote: Thank you so much bestbird. I know that it is ER/PR+. The original cancer was HER-, but my onc is having it tested to see what it is now. She did explain that I might be able to avoid chemo and do some type of hormone injection. I will definitely be getting a second opinion this time. I am a registered nurse, so fortunately I can understand most of what they are telling me. Right now, I am just praying I don't have mets in so many places that nothing can be done. I want to remain positive, and I am sure it will get easier, but right now I am already planning my funeral. Sorry to be a Debbie Downer. Hopefully, I can get some answers Monday when they go over my results, and develop a plan to keep it at bay. Your information is very helpful. Thanks again.
